data.title: 'The Predator' review: Ragtag team of colorful characters makes the movie
data.meta_description: The Predators are back, and it's up to a group of former soldiers and a biologist to save the world.
data.text:
A ragtag team of former soldiers makes 'The Predator' good, but it could have been better.

Critic's rating: 3.5 out of 5 stars

If you've heard anything about "The Predator" at this point, you might've heard about the controversy involving director Shane Black casting a registered sex offender.

Steven Wilder Striegel, the actor in question, had a small role with Olivia Munn that was cut after Munn told Fox.

Knowing the background drama beforehand could taint the appeal of the film that immediately follows the three standalone "Predator" movies.

Despite a solid storyline that adds to the series with a lively team of characters, there are parts of the film that could've been better.

Quinn McKenna (Boyd Holbrook) is a soldier on a hostage mission in Mexico with his unit when they encounter a Predator, a humanoid alien that hunts humans for sport. It has crashed its spacecraft in the middle of a confrontation. McKenna watches it murder his unit and he runs away while grabbing some of the alien's gear with him for insurance, which he sends back home.

Afterward, he's questioned by government officials who want to cover up the mission and proof of the alien encounter. McKenna knows they're true motives, so he's thrown onto a bus containing a group of ragtag ex-soldiers with robust individual personalities, varying forms of PTSD and colorful backstories to bury the Predator proof with McKenna.

Meanwhile, a government leader of alien investigation Project Stargazer (Sterling K. Brown) recruits biologist and university professor Dr. Casey Brackett (Munn) to examine the Predator that crashed. Of course, things go wrong. It wakes up and wrecks havoc on the scientists and soldiers in its path.

Remember that gear McKenna sent home? His young son Rory (Jacob Tremblay), who appears to have Asperger's syndrome, discovers how the gauntlet and helmet works, putting himself in danger.

It's up to Quinn, Casey and the ragtag bunch to save the world and McKenna's son.

The former soldiers that join Quinn on his journey are fantastic. The character development is so well done that you feel bad when something happens. Nebraska (Trevante Rhodes) by far has the most memorable personality of the group.

Coyle's (Keegan-Michael Key) wisecracks are funny if you like immature and offensive humor. The true comic relief comes from physical action, like when Quinn says he'll catch Casey and walks away right when she falls to the ground from the top of the bus.

Although, it isn't a "Predator" movie without a funny nod to "you're one ugly mother-(expletive)."

Even though the group is well-developed, it felt like Munn's character could've been better. It feels like the creators went heavy with the "you're the only girl in the unit so we're going to hit on you" jokes when it's clear that she can offer more than what was given.

She does realize that the Predators are evolving, an important plot point, but scenes like stripping to hide from a Predator outweigh her intellectual importance.

The movie's storyline as a whole fits in really well with the rest of the series, and it does a great job of paying homage to the original "Predator" movie by starting out in a jungle-like setting.

The Predators look great alongside "hunting dogs," and like always they're out for blood giving viewers flashes of gratuitous gory scenes.

Also, spoiler-free, the movie offers a great tease to a plot for the next movie (because no matter what they will continue to make these films for a long time).

But one detail involving disabilities was a bit irksome. Soldier Baxley (Thomas Jane) has Tourette syndrome, a disorder that causes a person to involuntarily twitch or make sounds. He's the butt of many jokes. Meanwhile Rory is "on the spectrum," but he's respected with his bright mind, and his disorder is a crucial attribute to the plot. Why respect one community and offend another?

No matter what you pick up from the film, sci-fi and "Predator" fans will like this film.

MORE REVIEWS:

Nicolas Cage at his crazy best in unhinged 'Mandy'

'White Boy Rick' is compelling — and problematic

'A Simple Favor:' Electric chemistry in comic mystery

'Bisbee '17' is cathartic history lesson

'The Predator,' 3.5 stars

Director: Shane Black

Cast: Boyd Holbrook, Trevante Rhodes, Jacob Tremblay, Keegan-Michael Key, Olivia Munn, Sterling K. Brown

Rating: R for strong bloody violence, language throughout, and crude sexual references.

Great ★★★★★ Good ★★★★

Fair ★★★ Bad ★★ Bomb ★
